Article In-situ Pt reduction induced topological transformation of NiFe-MOF for industrial seawater splitting Guohao Na a 1 Hongshun Zheng a 1 Mingpeng Chen a * Huachuan Sun a Yuewen Wu a Dequan Li a Yun Chen a Boran Zhao a Bo Zhao a Tong Zhou a Tianwei He a Yuxiao Zhang a Jianhong Zhao a Yumin Zhang a Jin Zhang a Feng Liu b Hao Cui b Qingju Liu a * a Yunnan Key Laboratory for Micro/Nano Materials & Technology, National Center for International Research on Photoelectric and Energy Materials, School of Materials and Energy, Yunnan University, Kunming 650091, Yunnan, China Yunnan Key Laboratory for Micro/Nano Materials & Technology National Center for International Research on Photoelectric and Energy Materials School of Materials and Energy Yunnan University Kunming Yunnan 650091 China Yunnan Key Laboratory for Micro/Nano Materials & Technology, National Center for International Research on Photoelectric and Energy Materials, School of Materials and Energy, Yunnan University, Kunming 650091, Yunnan, China b Yunnan Precious Metals Laboratory Co., Ltd., Kunming 650106, Yunnan, China Yunnan Precious Metals Laboratory Co., Ltd. Kunming Yunnan 650106 China Yunnan Precious Metals Laboratory Co., Ltd., Kunming 650106, Yunnan, China * Corresponding author. 1 Contributed equally to this work. Metal-support interaction (MSI) is regarded as an indispensable manner to stabilize active metals and modulate catalytic activity, which shows great potentials in developing of efficient hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) electrode with high activity and strong robustness. Herein, this work presents a novel heterostructure with ultrafine platinum quantum dots (Pt QDs) on defective catalytic supports derived from metal-organic frameworks (MOFs). It is indicated substantial oxygen vacancies can be generated and Pt–Pt bonds can be optimized through topological transformation. The resulting Pt/T-NiFe-BDC (BDC: C8H6O4) exhibits competitive HER activity in alkaline seawater, attaining ultralow overpotentials of 158 and 266 mV at 500 and 1000 mA cm–2 with fast kinetics and outstanding stability. An asymmetric water electrolyzer using Pt/T-NiFe-BDC as a cathode only requires a voltage of 1.89 V to generate an industrial density of 1000 mA cm–2 and shows no attenuation in 500-h continuous test at 500 mA cm–2. Theoretical calculations and in-situ spectroscopic analysis reveal the reversible hydrogen spillover mechanism, in which oxygen vacancies facilitate the sluggish water dissociation and Pt QDs promote the H* combination. This study provides a new paradigm to engineer metal-supported catalysts for efficient and robust seawater splitting. Graphical Abstract An innovative method is proposed to prepare Pt/T-NiFe-BDC, in which the topological transformation occurs to generate oxygen vacancies and enhance Pt–Pt bonds. This unique catalyst exhibits competitive HER activity in alkaline seawater. Keywords Seawater splitting Hydrogen evolution reaction Topological transformation Metal support interaction Reversible hydrogen spillover 1 Introduction Hydrogen (H2) is considered an ideal energy carrier for the global energy transformation from fossil fuels to clean energy resources due to its high energy density and environmental friendliness [1–3]. Electrochemical water splitting has been acknowledged as an extensively developed hydrogen production technology at industrial level [4]. Despite the pollution-free and high-efficiency merits have been earned, the significant shortage of freshwater resources hinders the scale-up application [5,6]. Fortunately, seawater, which accounts ~97% of the world’s water resources, seems to be a potential feedstock for water splitting [7]. Alkaline seawater splitting is a feasible approach, which not only suppresses the insoluble precipitation of Ca2+ and Mg2+ ions [8], but also provides a wide potential window for oxygen evolution reaction (OER) against chlorine oxidation reaction (ClOR) [9,10]. Compared with freshwater, the high content of Cl– in seawater may block active sites and cause catalyst corrosion, thus leading to unfavorable H* adsorption and poor catalytic stability[11,12]. To make breakthroughs in cathodic HER process from seawater [13], an ideal catalyst should be designed with exceptional intrinsic activity (moderate ΔGH* value) [14], high durability at industrial current densities, and excellent corrosion resistance [15]. Platinum exhibits desirable properties for HER, evidenced by nearly optimal ΔG H* in volcano plots according to the Sabatier principle [16,17]. However, commercial Pt/C catalysts face the problems of low Pt utilization efficiency and poor stability due to the weak interaction between Pt nanoparticles and carbon supports [18,19]. In contrast, a number of non-carbon supports feature great flexibility in components and structures, which endow tunable MSI and coordination environment, bringing vast opportunities in constructing various Pt-supported catalysts [20]. For instance, MOFs and their derivatives offer large specific surface area and adjustable morphology, endowing abundant active sites and fast charge/mass transfer [21]. For instance, Wang et al. [22,23] prepared metals/MOF heterojunctions with ultrasmall Pt QDs orientally growing on Ni-MOF nanosheets, realizing superior HER activities to commercial Pt/C in both acidic and alkaline media. The interface between metal QDs and support can cause a rearrangement of electrons within both materials, which has an obvious impact on the catalytic performance [24,25]. Generally, the size and composition of metal QDs are modulated to optimize the strong MSI and decrease the content of noble metal [26]. Therefore, transition metal based compounds have shown great potential in HER applications [27]. From another perspective, MOF-based substrates can provide precisely tunable coordination environments for the supported metal catalysts [28], thus delivering versatile MSI [29]. On one hand, noble metal precursors can be in-situ reduced on the redox-active MOFs without adding additional reducing reagents and realize the uniform growth of ultrafine noble metal clusters/particles [30]. On the other hand, the organic ligands are easy to be released and atomic defects can be generated subsequently [31]. There have been several post-synthesis treatments reported to tune the coordination environment after QD loading [32], which increased the complexity of preparation [33]. Given an intriguing example, Wang’s group integrated of Ru NPs on oxygen-deficient WO3–x , which was prepared by heat treatment in H2/Ar atmosphere and showed excellent proton storage ability [34,35]. When working as a cathode, protons would be transferred from WO3–x to Ru NPs to increase the hydrogen coverage on Ru NPs, improving the HER performance via reversible hydrogen spillover mechanism [36]. Despite numerous advantages, there were few studies that concentrated on introducing interfacial vacancies on supports to modulate MSI in a simple manner [37,38]. Herein, ultrafine Pt QDs were synthesized on defective catalytic supports derived from the MOF (NiFe-BDC) via topological transformation, namely Pt/T-NiFe-BDC. The derived support inherits the morphology of NiFe-BDC, while oxygen vacancies and Pt–Pt bonds can be well tuned to afford both high HER performance. Resultantly, the catalyst demonstrates ultralow overpotentials of 158 and 266 mV at 500 and 1000 mA cm–2 for HER in alkaline seawater. It is worth noting that Pt/T-NiFe-BDC has a superior stability over 500 h and high corrosion potential to inhibit Cl– corrosion. Besides, an water electrolyzer was assembled using Pt/T-NiFe-BDC as the cathode and NiFe-BDC as the anode, which only requires a voltage of 1.89 V to deliver an industrial density of 1000 mA cm–2 and shows no attenuation in 500 h continuous test at 500 mA cm–2. In combination of theoretical calculations and in-situ Raman results, the sluggish water dissociation can be facilitated by oxygen vacancies and the H* combination can be promoted by Pt QDs. The reversible hydrogen spillover mechanism is responsible for the significant enhancement of HER performance. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Nickel foam (NF, thickness: 1.0 mm) was acquired from Kunshan Guangjiayuan New Material Co., Ltd. Nickle nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, ≥98%) and hydrochloric acid (HCl) were purchased from Tianjin Windship Chemical Reagent Technology Co., Ltd. Iron(III) nitrate nonahydrate (Fe(NO3)2·9H2O, ≥99.5%), iron(III) chloride hexahydrate (FeCl3 6H2O, ≥99%), ruthenium(IV) oxide (RuO2, 99.9%), p-phthalic acid (C8H6O4 (BDC), 99%), N,N′-dimethylformamide (DMF, 99.5%), potassium hydroxide (KOH, 85%), and sodium chloride (NaCl, ≥99.5%) were purchased from Aladdin. Nafion solution (5 wt%) was bought from Sigma Aldrich Corporation. Platinum carbon (Pt/C, 20 wt%) was purchased from Suzhou Sinero Technology Co. Ltd. Chloroplatinic acid hydrate (H2PtCl6·XH2O, ≥38%) was obtained from Guiyan Platinum Co., Ltd. 2.2 Synthesis of the NiFe-BDC, Pt/T-NiFe-BDC and Pt/NiFe-BDC Firstly, a piece of NF (nickel foam, 2 × 3 cm2) was subsequently cleaned in 1 mol L–1 HCl, de-ionized (DI) water, and ethanol. Next, N,N′-dimethylformamide (DMF, 26 mL), ethanol (1.6 mL), and DI water (1.6 mL) were mixed, followed by the addition of 200 mg C8H6O4 and 1 mmol FeCl3·6H2O. After sufficient dissolution, the mixture was transferred into a stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 120 °C for 24 h. NiFe-BDC was cleaned, air-dried, and collected. Pt/T-NiFe-BDC was synthesized through an electrochemical deposition method, The optimized Pt/T-NiFe-BDC electrode was prepared by performing 50 cycles cyclic voltammetry (CV) between 0.1 and –0.3 V vs. RHE in the alkaline solution containing 0.5 mmol L–1 H2PtCl6. For comparison, 30 mL ethanol and 9 mg H2PtCl6 were thoroughly mixed and transferred to a stainless-steel autoclave with NiFe-BDC for a 12-h solvothermal reaction. Pt/NiFe-BDC could be collected after washing and air-drying at 60 °C. 2.3 Synthesis of the NiFe-LDH and Pt/NiFe-LDH A piece of cleaned NF was vertically immersed into a 50-mL Teflon autoclave filled with 40 mL aqueous solution containing 1 mmol Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, and 1 mmol Fe(NO3)2·9H2O. Subsequently, the Teflon autoclave was maintained at 100 °C for 8 h. Finally, NiFe-LDH was collected, cleaned, and air-dried at 60 °C. Pt/NiFe-LDH was synthesized by a similar method to Pt/T-NiFe-BDC. 2.4 Materials characterization Scanning electron microscopy (SEM, GeminiSEM 460), and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM-2100) were conducted to characterize the morphologies and structures of catalysts. Aberration-corrected high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) images were obtained on Thermofisher Spectra 300 equipped with a probe corrector. X-ray diffraction (XRD) data was recorded on an X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku TTR-III) with a Cu Kα source. X-Ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, K-Alpha) tests were conducted using Al source radiation. Raman spectra were recorded using a LabRAM HR Evolution Raman spectrometer (HORIBA) with a laser excitation of 532 nm. The elemental composition was determined by inductively coupled plasma emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) (Agilent 5110, 1.20 kW). X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) analysis was carried out at the BL11B beamlines of the Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility located in Shanghai, China, using Si {111} crystal monochromators. 2.5 Electrochemical measurements An EnergyLab XM potentiostat (Solartron Analytical) was utilized for electrochemical measurements in a conventional three-electrode system in 1 mol L–1 KOH and alkaline seawater. All potentials tested were calibrated to the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) scale: E RHE = E Hg/HgO + E 0 Hg/HgO + 0.0592pH(E 0 Hg/HgO 0.098V vs. RHE) The linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves were collected at a scan rate of 2 mV s–1 (Catalyst area 1 × 1 cm2) and are iR-corrected (95% compensation level). The (electrochemical impedance spectroscopy) EIS was recorded at an applied potential of 1.5 V vs. RHE from 100000 to 0.01Hz. The double layer capacitance (C dl) was determined in a non-Faradaic region (from the potential range 0.1 to 0.2 V and 0.05 to 0.15 V vs. Hg/HgO) at different scan rates. The ECSA were calculated based on C dl. In order to estimate the ECSA. The ECSA was calculated according to the following formula: ECSA = C dl/C s 2.6 Computational methods All spin-polarized density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed with the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) [39]. The exchange-correlation function was handled using the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) formulated by the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) [40]. The lane-wave basis set energy cutoff was set to 500 eV. Structural optimizations converged to within 1 × 10–5 eV and 0.02 eV Å–1. The electron states were sampled using a 3 × 2 × 1 k-point mesh of Γ-centered. For the Ni, Fe and Pt atoms, the U schemes need to be applied, and the U was set as 6.6, 3.5 and 2.4 eV [41], respectively. Vacuum layer in surface model was set to 15 Å. Following the optimization of structures, we evaluated catalytic properties by computing the H* adsorption Gibbs free energy. 3 Results and discussion As schematically illustrated in Fig. 1 , the Pt/T-NiFe-BDC electrode was prepared using a universal two-step method. Firstly, stacked ultrathin NiFe-BDC nanosheets were vertically grown on NF as a precursor. Then, well-dispersed Pt NPs were in-situ formed by electrodeposition in 1 mol L–1 KOH + H2PtCl6 on the NiFe-BDC support, which simultaneously converted into NiFe layered double hydroxide (NiFe-LDH) nanosheets via topological transformation. It can be observed that the color of electrode noticeably darkens after Pt loading (Fig. S1). By ICP-OES analysis, the actual contents of Pt, Fe and Ni in Pt/T-NiFe-BDC were determined to be ~1.2, ~15.9 and ~25.1 wt%, respectively (Fig. S2). Firstly, NiFe-BDC nanosheets with a lateral size of 3-4 μm were grown on NF, which were densely and tightly stacked into a granular structure (Fig. 2(a) ). The main peaks of XRD pattern of NiFe-BDC are observed at 16.4°, 18.5°, 31.3°, and 33.4° (Fig. S3), well matching with {110}, {220}, {112}, and {330} crystal planes of the reported model structure (CCDC No. 985792) [42]. Upon the introduction of Pt QDs by electrodeposition, Pt/T-NiFe-BDC inherited the stacked nanosheet structure of NiFe-BDC without any deterioration (Fig. 2(b)). Unexpectedly, the XRD peaks change into 12.1°, 23.4°, 35.0°, and 39.8°, indicating the {003}, {202}, {012}, and {015} crystal planes of NiFe-LDH (JCPDS 38-0715) [43], respectively (Fig. S3). Raman measurements indicate the existence of carboxyl groups (1426 and 1615 cm–1) in NiFe-BDC. However, these vibrational bands disappear in Pt/T-NiFe-BDC, while the peaks of M–O and M–OH (335, 481, and 673 cm–1) bending vibration bands are enhanced (Fig. S4). It can be elucidated that the topological transformation happens to NiFe-BDC along with the fast release of organic ligands. By contrast, Pt QDs were decorated on NiFe-LDH and NiFe-BDC supports to obtain Pt/NiFe-LDH and Pt/NiFe-BDC. Both supports retain their own morphology and crystal phase (Figs. S5, S6). Evidently, the XRD peaks of Pt/NiFe-BDC completely coincide with those of NiFe-BDC (Fig. S7). No obvious XRD peaks related to Pt metal can be observed. To determine the existence of Pt in Pt/T-NiFe-BDC, the fine structure of catalyst was studied by using TEM and HAADF-STEM. The nanosheet structure is exfoliated by ultrasonic treatment, and each flake has a width within 100 nm (Fig. 2(c)). For a more detailed description, an enlarged HAADF-STEM image indicates that Pt QDs are uniformly loaded on the catalyst surface (Fig. 2(d)), and the lattice fringes of 0.26 and 0.22 nm can be indexed to the (202) crystal plane of NiFe-LDH and the (111) crystal plane of Pt metal (Fig. 2(e)). The average diameter of Pt QDs is calculated to be 2.3 nm and no aggregated nanoparticles are observed for Pt/T-NiFe-BDC (Fig. 2(f)). Besides, the identical exposed (111) plane of Pt are also observed in Pt/NiFe-LDH and Pt/NiFe-BDC, and the lattice fringe corresponding to (202) crystal plane of NiFe-LDH is only witnessed in Pt/NiFe-LDH (Figs. S8 and S9). These findings are consistent with XRD measurements. Element mapping images (Figs. 2(g), S10–S12) confirm that the presence and dispersion of Pt, Ni, Fe, and O are uniform across Pt/T-NiFe-BDC, Pt/NiFe-LDH, and Pt/NiFe-BDC. As shown in Fig. 3(a) , the room temperature electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) measurement was performed to detect vacancy defects. The variation of signal intensities at g = 2.005 indicates that different numbers of electrons trapped in oxygen vacancies. Apparently, the signal intensity follows the trend of Pt/T-NiFe-BDC > NiFe-BDC > Pt/NiFe-LDH > Pt/NiFe-BDC, indicating that the concentration of oxygen vacancies greatly increases along with the release of ligands during the topological transformation. Subsequently, the changes in the electronic configurations were characterized by XPS. XPS survey spectra (Fig. S13) confirm the coexistence of corresponding elements in accordance with element mapping images. Fig. 3(b) depicts the O 1s spectra of Pt/T-NiFe-BDC, NiFe-BDC, and Pt/NiFe-LDH, and the deconvoluted peaks of Pt/T-NiFe-BDC at 529.2, 530.4, 531.3, and 532.3 eV are attributed to lattice oxygen (OL), surficial O-H bonds (OOH), oxygen vacancies (OV), and adsorbed water (Ow), respectively [44,45]. Remarkably, rich oxygen vacancies can be identified in the Pt/T-NiFe-BDC catalyst. Compared with NiFe-BDC, and Pt/NiFe-LDH, the peak positions of Pt/T-NiFe-BDC show a negative shift, which is ascribed to a higher electron density of O. It is obvious that the Fe 2p spectrum of NiFe-BDC can be deconvoluted into six peaks, while the peaks at 710.9 and 723.8 eV are related to Fe3+ 2p 3/2 and Fe3+ 2p 1/2, and the peaks at 710.5 and 723.4 eV are related to Fe2+ 2p 3/2 and Fe2+ 2p 1/2 (Fig. 3(c)). The other two satellite peaks are distinguished at 717.5 and 731.3 eV, respectively [46]. After Pt deposition, the Fe 2p spectrum of Pt/T-NiFe-BDC shows a positive shift (0.4 eV), indicating that Fe site tends to lose electrons for Pt2+ reduction. As shown in Fig. 3(d), the peaks located at 855.7/872.9 eV and 857.1/875.2 eV belong to Ni2+ and Ni3+ species, while the satellite peaks are located at 862.4 and 879.8 eV [47]. It can be observed that there is no shift in the binding energy before and after Pt deposition, indicating that Ni barely contributes to Pt2+ reduction. In addition, the high-resolution Pt 4f spectra of Pt/T-NiFe-BDC and Pt/NiFe-LDH can be deconvoluted into four characteristic peaks, including Pt0 (71.2 and 74.5 eV) and Pt2+ (73.8 and 77.0 eV) (Fig. S14). Above all, we deduce that Pt QDs on the NiFe-BDC derived support can regulate the electron transfer, resulting in an enhanced MSI. To further comprehend the local structure of Pt QDs, the X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) spectra of Pt K-edge were analyzed. Fig. 3(e) indicates that the absorption edges of Pt/T-NiFe-BDC and Pt/NiFe-LDH are close to that of Pt foil, indicating the metallic characteristics of Pt [48]. In the magnified image, the absorption edge positions of Pt/T-NiFe-BDC and Pt/NiFe-LDH are located at the middle of Pt foil and PtO2, identifying that the average valence state of Pt atoms in the two samples is similar. In the X-ray absorption fine structures (EXAFS) spectra at the Pt L3 edge (Fig. 3(f)), the two peaks of Pt/NiFe-LDH at ~1.2 and ~2.3 Å belong to Pt–O and Pt–Pt, respectively. Besides, the detailed atomic coordination environment can be well analyzed by the EXAFS spectra with Fourier transform (Fig. S15, and Table S1). Notably, the Pt–Pt bond peak of Pt/T-NiFe-BDC slightly shifts towards lower R values (2.26 → 2.18 Å), which is attributed to a shorter distance between the central Pt atom and the surrounding coordinated Pt atoms. This compressive strain in Pt QDs ensures its stable loading [49]. The coordination structure can also be confirmed through k 2-weighted wavelet transform (WT) analysis (Fig. 3(g)) [50]. The emergence of weak Pt-O coordination is originated from the interfacial Pt-O-M (M: Ni, Fe) bridge, leading to the tunable charge distribution and improved conductivity [51,52]. The predominant Pt–Pt bonds in Pt/T-NiFe-BDC not only accelerates electron transfer but also improves the stability of catalyst [53]. The HER performance of as-prepared catalysts was evaluated by using a standard three-electrode system. To select the optimal deposition conditions, Pt deposition was conducted in H2PtCl6 solutions with different concentrations (4, 6, 7, 10, and 14 mmol L–1). As the concentration increases, HER performance continued to improve until the concentration reaches 7mM/L. Additional increase of concentration is useless to further improve the performance (Fig. S16). We firstly evaluated the HER performance of all catalysts in 1 mol L–1 KOH. The LSV curve of Pt/T-NiFe-BDC (Fig. 4(a) ) shows that the overpotentials of Pt/T-NiFe-BDC are as low as 140 and 225 mV to attain current densities of 500 and 1000 mA cm–2, which are much lower than that of Pt/NiFe-LDH (177 and 311 mV) and Pt/NiFe-BDC (267 and 415 mV). When small current densities of 10, 50, and 100 mA cm–2 are selected as comparison parameters, Pt/T-NiFe-BDC also exhibits the best HER activity, requiring overpotentials of 20, 44, and 62 mV (Fig. S17(a)). Pt/T-NiFe-BDC owns the lowest Tafel slope (32 mV dec–1) in comparison with the other three catalysts (37, 41, 49 mV dec–1) (Figs. 4(b) and (c)). The EIS indicates that Pt/T-NiFe-BDC has the fastest charge transfer rate. The Nyquist plot is fitted using the Randles equivalent circuit, where Rct represents the charge transfer resistance. Pt/T-NiFe-BDC exhibits 0.4 Ω cm–2 at a potential of –1 V vs. Hg/HgO (Fig. 4(b), S17(b)), which is much lower than Pt/NiFe-LDH (1.1 Ω cm–2) and Pt/NiFe-BDC (1.9 Ω cm–2) (Table S2). The electrocatalytic active surface area (ECSA) of an electrocatalyst is proportional to the electrochemical C dl, which can be estimated by recording cyclic voltammetry (CV) in the non-Faraday region at different scan rates (20–100 mV s–1). The C dl values of the electrodes were calculated to be 83.2 (Pt/T-NiFe-BDC), 62.4 (Pt/NiFe-LDH), and 16.7 mF cm–2 (Pt/NiFe-BDC), respectively (Fig. S18). In addition, the calculated ECSA follows the trend Pt/T-NiFe-BDC (41.6 cm2) > Pt/NiFe-LDH (31.2 cm2) > Pt/NiFe-BDC (8.4 cm2), indicating the highest concentration of active sites on NiFe-BDC. This indicates that Pt QDs and oxygen vacancies synergistically enhance the intrinsic activity of the catalyst. At the same time, we prepared a series of NiFe-MOFs with different morphologies, and Pt QDs can be loaded on these NiFe-MOFs by using the same method. These Pt-decorated catalysts also exhibit good HER/OER performance (Figs. S19, S20). Considering the scarcity of global freshwater, seawater splitting is a promising and sustainable way of hydrogen production. Given the superior HER performance of Pt/NiFe-LDH, we further investigated its catalytic activity in alkaline seawater (1 mol L–1 KOH + seawater). Impressively, the overpotential of Pt/T-NiFe-BDC in alkaline seawater is as low as 160 mV at the current density of 500 mA cm–2 (Fig. 4(d)). Surprisingly, Pt/T-NiFe-BDC effectively repels chloride ions in seawater, as reflected in the corrosion kinetics information. The corrosion current (I corr) and corrosion voltage (E corr) were extrapolated in a simulated corrosion environment (2 mV s–1, ±500 mA) and calculated to be 50.3 mA cm–2 and –1.13 V, respectively, indicating the minimum corrosion trend and corrosion rate (Fig. 4(e)) [54]. Long-term stability is an important parameter to evaluate the feasibility of catalysts in practical applications. We conducted a chronopotentiometry measurement test in alkaline seawater at the constant current density of 500 mA cm–2 for 500 h, and only slight changes are identified (Fig. 4(f)). The cyclic durability was studied using continuous CV scans of 100 mV s–1. After 10000 CV cycles, there are only minor differences compared to the original LSV curve. After HER test, the structural robustness of the catalyst was characterized. SEM, TEM, XRD, and EDS characterization of Pt/T-NiFe-BDC after HER test consistently indicate its excellent structural stability, including morphology, crystal structure, and elemental distribution. (Figs. S21, S22). The Ni 2p, Fe 2p, Pt 4f, and O 1s regions in XPS spectra show negligible changes (Figs. S23, S24). These results are consistent with the extraordinary HER stability of Pt/T-NiFe-BDC. Besides, Pt/T-NiFe-BDC exhibits superior catalytic activity, surpassing the state-of-art catalysts (Figs. 4(g) and S25, and Table S3, S4). In practical applications, electrocatalysts generate many bubbles on their surfaces at high current densities. These bubbles may hinder the diffusion of electrolytes and block the exposure of active sites. To study the characteristics of bubble desorption, we recorded the release behavior of bubbles during water splitting using digital photographs (Fig. S26). Obviously, the bubbles generated on the surface of Pt/T-NiFe-BDC are smaller and easier to release into the electrolyte, with an average diameter of 170 ± 36 μm. The bubbles on Pt/NiFe-LDH tend to accumulate into larger sizes of 248 ± 41 μm, which are more difficult to release. To investigate the effect of Pt content on OER performance, Pt deposition was carried out in H2PtCl6 solutions with various concentrations (4, 6, 7, 10, and 14 mmol L–1). The OER performance exhibits only a slight improvement with increasing concentration (Fig. S27). Surprisingly, NiFe-BDC exhibits excellent catalytic performance toward OER at high current densities. The LSV curves demonstrate that NiFe BDC only requires 299 and 342 mV to achieve the current densities of 500 and 1000 mA cm–2, which are much smaller than NiFe-LDH (359 and 412 mV), RuO2, and NF (Fig. 5(a) ). As shown in Fig. 5(b), compared with NiFe-LDH (36.8mV dec–1), NiFe-BDC has the lowest Tafel slope (21.2 mV dec–1) (Fig. S28(a)). The C dl of NiFe-BDC (5.7 mF cm–2) is higher than that of NiFe-LDH (4.2 mF cm–2) (Fig. S29). In addition, the EIS results showed that the ultra-low R ct of NiFe-BDC was only 0.45 Ω cm–2 lower than that of NiFe-LDH (2.19 Ω cm–2) (Fig. S28(b), Table S6). As a result, all catalysts show only negligible improvement in OER performance after Pt deposition (Fig. S30). Comparing the performance of the catalyst in 1 mol L–1 KOH and alkaline seawater, it was found that NiFe LDH exhibits significant attenuation compared to NiFe BDC (Fig. 5(c)). In the simulated corrosion environment, the corrosion current density (I corr) and corrosion potential (E corr) were determined to be 47.7 mA cm–2 and 1.03 V, respectively, indicating the high corrasion resistance of NiFe-BDC (Fig. S31). Given the remarkable HER performance of Pt/T-NiFe-BDC and the excellent OER performance of NiFe-BDC, we assembled a dual electrode system for high current overall alkaline seawater splitting using Pt/T-NiFe-BDC and NiFe-BDC electrodes as cathodes and anodes. As shown in Fig. 5(d), at room temperature, only low battery voltages of 1.71 and 1.89 V are required to achieve current densities of 500 and 1000 mA cm–2. Pt/T-NiFe-BDC || NiFe-BDC undergoes a long-term test at 500 mA cm–2 for 500 h. Besides, NiFe-BDC was subjected to a 200-h stability test in seawater at a current density of 100 mA cm–2, in which negligible attenuation can be observed (Figs. 5(e) and S32). The excellent performance of Pt/T-NiFe-BDC||NiFe-BDC in overall alkaline seawater water splitting far exceeds that of Pt/C||RuO2, and surpasses recently reported HER/OER catalysts in alkaline seawater electrolytes (Fig. 5(f), Table S7). To substantiate that reversible hydrogen spillover mechanism can improve HER performance, DFT calculations were subsequently performed. Based on the visualization results of charge density difference maps, the presence of O vacancies (OV) leads to the charge redistribution of NiFe-BDC, which can effectively enhance MSI and promote catalytic stability (Figs. 6(a) , S33). The projected density of state (PDOS) of PtQD in both Pt/T-NiFe-BDC and Pt/NiFe-LDH were depicted (Fig. 6(b)). The presence of Ov can optimize the position of d-band center of PtQD in Pt/T-NiFe-BDC, weakening the bonding strength with the adsorbent, which is favorable for HER. Considering the whole HER pathway on Pt/T-NiFe-BDC and Pt/NiFe-LDH, the initial dissociation of H2O molecule is widely recognized as a crucial step in alkaline HER. OV and PtQD were chosen as the adsorption sites of H2O molecules in Pt/T-NiFe-BDC, while PtQD serves as the adsorption site in Pt/NiFe-LDH. (Figs. 6(c), (d) and S34). It is evident that the energy barrier of H2O dissociation at OV sites (–0.45 eV) is better than that at PtQD sites (-1.63 eV), and it is much lower than PtQD sites on Pt/NiFe-LDH (0.86 eV). This indicates that the presence of OV can accelerate the dissociation of H2O molecules into *OH and *H, which activates the reversible hydrogen spillover mechanism. Furthermore, compared with Pt/T-NiFe-BDC-PtQD and Pt/NiFe-LDH-PtQD, Pt/T-NiFe-BDC-OV exhibits a reduced energy barrier for the *H desorption, which kinetically allows fast H2 formation. Above all, the existence of OV can promote reversible hydrogen spillover to significantly improve HER performance of Pt/T-NiFe-BDC. The above results were further verified by spectroscopic analysis. In terms of the in-situ Raman characterization, the broad peak ranging from 2800 to 3800 cm–1 is assigned to the O-H stretching mode (τO-H) of H2O molecules on catalyst surface [55,56], which is deconvoluted by Gauss fitting into three peaks. Specifically, tetrahedral coordinated H2O (τ1), trihedral coordinated H2O (τ2), and dangling O-H bonds (τ3) are identified at ~3222.3, ~3425.8, and ~3602.3 cm–1, respectively (Figs. 6(e), (f)) [57]. In general, τ3 can convert into ordered H-down structures easily. As shown in Fig. 6(g), the number of dangling O–H bonds on Pt/T-NiFe-BDC and Pt/NiFe-LDH gradually increase with the negative potential. At a potential of –0.6 V vs. RHE, the ratio of τ3 reaches 9.8%, which is higher than the 7.9% of Pt/NiFe-LDH. More dangling O–H bonds will disrupt the hydrogen bond network, thereby accelerating the Heyrovsky and Volmer steps. With the increase of HER potential, Pt/T-NiFe-BDC shows a faster downward trend than Pt/NiFe-LDH, indicating that oxygen deficient Pt/T-NiFe-BDC has a more effective ability to dissociate O–H bonds of H2O molecules (Fig. S35) [58]. Furthermore, no significant changes in the vibrational peaks were observed in the 100–2000 cm–1 with the increasing voltage, proving the strong stability of catalyst’s surface structure (Fig. S36). 4 Conclusions In conclusion, we proposed an innovative method to introduce Pt QDs on the NiFe-BDC derived support, in which the unique topological transformation occurs to generate a number of oxygen vacancies and enhance Pt–Pt bonds. The reversible hydrogen spillover mechanism is revealed by DFT calculations and in-situ Raman measurements, elucidating that oxygen vacancies promote the slow water dissociation and Pt QDs boost the generation and release of H2 molecules. Benefiting from the tunable MSI and synergistic effect, Pt/T-NiFe-BDC exhibits competitive HER activity in alkaline seawater with ultralow overpotential of 158 and 266 mV at 500 and 1000 mA cm–2, respectively. In addition, this catalyst shows rare attenuation for 500-h continuous test at the industrial current density. Our findings provide a feasible strategy for designing high-performance HER electrocatalysts and a new perspective for understanding the structure-activity relationship. coredata.dc:description: Metal-support interaction (MSI) is regarded as an indispensable manner to stabilize active metals and modulate catalytic activity, which shows great potentials in developing of efficient hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) electrode with high activity and strong robustness. Herein, this work presents a novel heterostructure with ultrafine platinum quantum dots (Pt QDs) on defective catalytic supports derived from metal-organic frameworks (MOFs). It is indicated substantial oxygen vacancies can be generated and Pt–Pt bonds can be optimized through topological transformation. The resulting Pt/T-NiFe-BDC (BDC: C8H6O4) exhibits competitive HER activity in alkaline seawater, attaining ultralow overpotentials of 158 and 266 mV at 500 and 1000 mA cm–2 with fast kinetics and outstanding stability. An asymmetric water electrolyzer using Pt/T-NiFe-BDC as a cathode only requires a voltage of 1.89 V to generate an industrial density of 1000 mA cm–2 and shows no attenuation in 500-h continuous test at 500 mA cm–2. Theoretical calculations and in-situ spectroscopic analysis reveal the reversible hydrogen spillover mechanism, in which oxygen vacancies facilitate the sluggish water dissociation and Pt QDs promote the H* combination. This study provides a new paradigm to engineer metal-supported catalysts for efficient and robust seawater splitting.
